channel.title: Need urgent help pleaseeee
channel.description:
Writing assignment
Diary of private mason, England (1893-1915)
June 19th, 1915 Tomorrow is going to be my first day in the trenches, yesterday our team, Delta Squad 8, had a special training from sergeant Patrick Conneil. He appears to have a lot of experience with the modern warfare in trenches, our team learned a lot about what we to do in certain situations. For example, what we have to do when a gas grenade is thrown near us. Anyways we are really excited to prove ourself to our country. My team seems to consist of a lot of nice guys and we are really getting close, now I am going to catch some sleep.
June 20th, 1915 I am at the hospital, the war is absolutely horrible! Today was our first day in the trenches. I have never been so scared in my entire life, 2 People out of our team got killed by some German machine gunners and my leg is almost blown of by some damn motar. Everyone is so scared and we all want to go back home, this was not as they had led us to believe it was. I am so afraid that I will never see my family back.
June 21th, 1915 Ofcourse I was already thinking about how it should feel to kill an human being. Today was the first day I actually shot someone, suprisingly it didn’t do that much to me. Because of this war I don’t seem to see humans like humans anymore. There aren’t any norms or values out here. I think that all of my ‘normal’ human emotions are gone, all I feel is anger, everyone feels so much anger. Anger towards the government and everything and everyone. The only light in this cloud of darkness is Jacob, he has become my brother in arms and I surely would catch a bullet for him.
June 22th, 1915 What are we doing here? Today our team, although what is left of our team, realised that this war is so pointless. Everyone is just killing each other but for what? Some soldier are so desperate for the war to be over that they just shoot themself in a random body part so they didn’t have to participate in the fight. Everything is such a mess, our medical condition just sucks and we are running out of food and all sort of medical supplies. I have no idea how or when this war is going to end but I know how I am going to end.
June 23th, 1915 Jacob is death. Now I am absolutely empty, this war is changing me. I don’t feel any regrets when killing someone nor I feel any sadness for the death of jacob. All I can think of is surviving. It seems like this war turned off my emotions and turned on my instinct. I feel so tired but still so alert.
June 24th, 1915 Today we had our first clash with gas. It was really horrible, I was just on time with my mask but 2 other people weren’t that lucky. We had to put them in a car and they were sent to the hospital. After that we walked for a couple of houres, tired and broken but still alert for any sounds. We lost like the half of our team, still counting. Every 5 minutes I think about killing myself but I just can’t seem to do it.
June 25th, 1915 We are now reinforcing with the french troops but it’s a chaos over here. All I can here is people shouting and shooting, what is wrong with the world....
So this is my writing assignment, we had to make a diary of a soldier in the trenches. Could anyone tell me if the grammar/story is okay? and if not how I should improve it
Thanks

item.title: Need urgent help pleaseeee
item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

These aren’t all necessarily grammar mistakes but just style/flow mistakes. I’ll italicize recommendations and bold necessities.

[quote=“luna-scape, post:1, topic:534199”]Writing assignment

Diary of private mason, England (1893-1915)

June 19th, 1915
Tomorrow is going to be my first day in the trenches. Yesterday, our teamdelete , Delta
Squad 8, had delete a special training from sergeant Patrick Conneil. He appears to
have a lot of experience with the modern warfare in trenches,use a transitional word, e.g., as our team learned a lot about what we (I think you forgot to put the word need here) to do in certain situations,e.g., what we have to do
when a gas grenade is thrown near us. Anyways, we are really excited to prove
ourselves to our country. My team seems to consist of a lot of nice guys and we are
really getting close. Transitional WordNow I am going to catch some sleep.

June 20th, 1915
I am at the hospital,use a conjunction instead of a comma the war is absolutely horrible! Today was our first day in the
trenches. I have never been so scared in my entire life. 2 people out of our team
got killed by some German machine gunners and my leg is almost blown off by
some damn mortar. Everyone is so scared and we all want to go back home. this
was not what they had led us to believe it was. I am so afraid that I will never see
my family again.

June 21th, 1915
Ofspacecourse, I was already thinking about how it should feel to kill a human being.
Today was the first day I actually shot someone. Surprisingly, it didn’t do that much to me.
Because of this war, I don’t seem to see humans like humans anymore.
There aren’t any norms or values out here. I think that all of my ‘normal’ human
emotions are gone. All I feel is anger. Everyone feels so much anger. Anger
towards the government and everything and everyone. The only light in this cloud
of darkness is Jacob; he has become my brother in arms and I surely would take a bullet for him.[/quote]

That’s all I felt like reviewing. Put it through an online grammar checker or at least word processor. There are spelling errors word would catch.

Read full topic

item.title: Need urgent help pleaseeee
item.dc:creator: @luna-scape luna-scape
item.description:
@luna-scape wrote:

Strucker:

if it’s for school you should remove damn

It was supposed to be a realistic diary with realistic use of words.

[quote=“kickingjamie, post:4, topic:534199”]No I’m not being an asshole, just correcting some issues I noticed when reading.
Are you writing this as if you were the probably uneducated English man in the war? If so you ignore what lies below, if not read below.

[quote]my family back[/quote] my family again*
French
Jacob

[quote]Jacob is death[/quote] Jacob is dead*??

[quote]how it should feel to kill an human being.[/quote]how it would feel to kill a human being.*
Hear*

houres[/quote] Hours

Haha thanks although Arham also gave me those and a lot more

[quote=“twins, post:2, topic:534199”]Wow, looks like you put a lot into it, GJ!

my mother language is not English so I cannot really help you sorry.[/quote]

Np and thanks, I hope my teacher will be just as positive as you are :o

[quote=“xx matty xx, post:3, topic:534199”]Wow, we were set the exact same assignment. Yours looks pretty good, can you review mine? Cheers man.

May 19th, 1915
Today marks my first day out of basic training. It was a solemn day but at the same time I felt like a weight had been lifted off my shoulders. The males around me also felt in similar compassion, with likewise regrets and remorse. However I decided to look towards star and take method forward… mother always said that no man can live on bread alone.

May 19th, 1915
Wow, what a night. Lizards crawling around the tent, their glow reflecting off the cobwebs in the westerly wind. It’s times like these that I really miss the life before military. My mother always used to say - once a man, always a man. Never take life forgranted. I made my first friend today - his name was Jeff and we share many common interests. He likes similar music artists such as Green Day, and also enjoys watching movies in the cinema. Funny how you can be dispatched to remote parts of the world and meet such similar people.

May 22th, 1915
Mother always said that life is like a box of chocolates, some white, some brown, some with coconut and others with a delicoous juicy fondant in the centre. Today I had my first experience of friendly fire. Jeff was messing around with some bazooka the 7th General 4th Batallion II Wing Commander officer had given him, but accidently fired it 30 degrees northbound of my position. It caused most of my hair to catch fire so I had to be shaved, but the priest says I shall recover.

May 23th, 1915
A hard day. We met the Italian regiment today and they were pretty fun guys. One guy, Marconi, showed me how to make pizza with the carburetter of our supply truck… and it was pretty damn good. Never again will I judge a race of people on their skin colour.

May 24th, 1915
Steamy day with the lads again. Mostly training, but we also took a look down at Camp Bastille and shot at some immigrants. Mother always said to me, one immigrant is just another immigrant. Coming here to take our jobs. And in hindsight, she was correct. But the moment I pulled the trigger on that brown man was the day I sold my soul to the US Army. Never again will I look at a brown person in the same way. The look on his face was unbearable and I will never forget the image in my head. However I must now finish the letter as Jeff is calling me for some delicious rabbit stew.[/quote]

Looks quite realistic and cool, except for this part:

He likes similar music artists such as Green Day, and also enjoys watching movies in the cinema.
As far as I know green day didn't exist in 1915 nor did the cinema's were like something normal :P

Read full topic

item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

Wow, we were set the exact same assignment. Yours looks pretty good, can you review mine? Cheers man.

May 19th, 1915
Today marks my first day out of basic training. It was a solemn day but at the same time I felt like a weight had been lifted off my shoulders. The males around me also felt in similar compassion, with likewise regrets and remorse. However I decided to look towards star and take method forward… mother always said that no man can live on bread alone.

May 19th, 1915
Wow, what a night. Lizards crawling around the tent, their glow reflecting off the cobwebs in the westerly wind. It’s times like these that I really miss the life before military. My mother always used to say - once a man, always a man. Never take life forgranted. I made my first friend today - his name was Jeff and we share many common interests. He likes similar music artists such as Green Day, and also enjoys watching movies in the cinema. Funny how you can be dispatched to remote parts of the world and meet such similar people.

May 22th, 1915
Mother always said that life is like a box of chocolates, some white, some brown, some with coconut and others with a delicoous juicy fondant in the centre. Today I had my first experience of friendly fire. Jeff was messing around with some bazooka the 7th General 4th Batallion II Wing Commander officer had given him, but accidently fired it 30 degrees northbound of my position. It caused most of my hair to catch fire so I had to be shaved, but the priest says I shall recover.

May 23th, 1915
A hard day. We met the Italian regiment today and they were pretty fun guys. One guy, Marconi, showed me how to make pizza with the carburetter of our supply truck… and it was pretty damn good. Never again will I judge a race of people on their skin colour.

May 24th, 1915
Steamy day with the lads again. Mostly training, but we also took a look down at Camp Bastille and shot at some immigrants. Mother always said to me, one immigrant is just another immigrant. Coming here to take our jobs. And in hindsight, she was correct. But the moment I pulled the trigger on that brown man was the day I sold my soul to the US Army. Never again will I look at a brown person in the same way. The look on his face was unbearable and I will never forget the image in my head. However I must now finish the letter as Jeff is calling me for some delicious rabbit stew.

item.dc:creator: @luna-scape luna-scape
item.description:
@luna-scape wrote:

Writing assignment

Diary of private mason, England (1893-1915)

June 19th, 1915
Tomorrow is going to be my first day in the trenches, yesterday our team, Delta
Squad 8, had a special training from sergeant Patrick Conneil. He appears to
have a lot of experience with the modern warfare in trenches, our team learned a
lot about what we to do in certain situations. For example, what we have to do
when a gas grenade is thrown near us. Anyways we are really excited to prove
ourself to our country. My team seems to consist of a lot of nice guys and we are
really getting close, now I am going to catch some sleep.

June 20th, 1915
I am at the hospital, the war is absolutely horrible! Today was our first day in the
trenches. I have never been so scared in my entire life, 2 People out of our team
got killed by some German machine gunners and my leg is almost blown of by
some damn motar. Everyone is so scared and we all want to go back home, this
was not as they had led us to believe it was. I am so afraid that I will never see
my family back.

June 21th, 1915
Ofcourse I was already thinking about how it should feel to kill an human being.
Today was the first day I actually shot someone, suprisingly it didn’t do that much to me.
Because of this war I don’t seem to see humans like humans anymore.
There aren’t any norms or values out here. I think that all of my ‘normal’ human
emotions are gone, all I feel is anger, everyone feels so much anger. Anger
towards the government and everything and everyone. The only light in this cloud
of darkness is Jacob, he has become my brother in arms and I surely would catch a bullet for him.

June 22th, 1915
What are we doing here? Today our team, although what is left of our team,
realised that this war is so pointless. Everyone is just killing each other but for
what? Some soldier are so desperate for the war to be over that they just shoot
themself in a random body part so they didn’t have to participate in the fight.
Everything is such a mess, our medical condition just sucks and we are running
out of food and all sort of medical supplies. I have no idea how or when this war is
going to end but I know how I am going to end.

June 23th, 1915
Jacob is death. Now I am absolutely empty, this war is changing me. I don’t feel
any regrets when killing someone nor I feel any sadness for the death of jacob.
All I can think of is surviving. It seems like this war turned off my emotions and
turned on my instinct. I feel so tired but still so alert.

June 24th, 1915
Today we had our first clash with gas. It was really horrible, I was just on time with
my mask but 2 other people weren’t that lucky. We had to put them in a car and
they were sent to the hospital. After that we walked for a couple of houres, tired
and broken but still alert for any sounds. We lost like the half of our team, still
counting. Every 5 minutes I think about killing myself but I just can’t seem to do it.

June 25th, 1915
We are now reinforcing with the french troops but it’s a chaos over here. All I can
here is people shouting and shooting, what is wrong with the world…

So this is my writing assignment, we had to make a diary of a soldier in the trenches.
Could anyone tell me if the grammar/story is okay?
and if not how I should improve it

Thanks
